content.text: Measure and record the length \(L\) of the wire between the nails on the wooden strip, as shown in Fig. 1.1

content.text: You have also been provided with a wire labelled A with crocodile clips at its ends
Set up the circuit shown in Fig. 1.2
F, G, H and J are crocodile clips
The distance between one of the nails and H is \(d\), as shown in Fig. 1.2. Attach H to the wire on the wooden strip so that \(d\) is approximately \(20 \text{cm}\)
Close the switch
Record the value of \(d\) and the voltmeter readings \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\)
d =

content.text: Increase \(d\) by placing H at different positions on the wire and record \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\)
Repeat until you have six sets of readings of \(d\), \(V_{1}\) and \(V_{2}\). Include your values from **(b)**
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(\left(\frac{V_2}{V_1}\right)d\) and \(d^2\) in your table
Plot a graph of \(\left(\frac{V_2}{V_1}\right)d\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(d^2\) on the \(x\)-axis
Draw the straight line of best fit
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line

In this experiment, you will investigate an electrical circuit
You have been provided with a wooden strip with a wire attached
● Set up the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1

Hold the \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass so that the string is horizontal and as straight as possible and the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass is as close to the rod of the clamp as possible. The string should be resting on the rod of the clamp
When the \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass is released, the \(100\mathrm{g}\) mass will fall downwards
The \(10\mathrm{g}\) mass will fall and move towards the stand
The string will wrap itself several times around the rod of the clamp
You may need to repeat the procedure several times before you see this result
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(A\). Show your working
percentage uncertainty = .........%
Hold the string so that \(\theta\) is approximately \(65^{\circ}\)
Release the \(10 \text{g}\) mass
The distance fallen by the \(100 \text{g}\) mass is \(H\), as shown in Fig. 2.4
Measure and record \(\theta\) and \(H\)

In this experiment, you will investigate the motion of two connected masses
You have been provided with two masses connected by a string
The larger mass is \(100\mathrm{g}\) and the smaller mass is \(10\mathrm{g}\)
Describe **four** improvements that could be made to this experiment. You may suggest the use of other apparatus or different procedures
